Energy Saving, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China 1 Orcid: 000–003-2862–0992 In the reaction of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and 2,4-diaminotoluene (TDA), Au/CeO2 exhibits higher selectivity than CeO2 for dimethyl toluene-2,4-dicarbamate (TDC). However, its catalytic activity drops after H2 reduction (denoted as Au/CeO2-R). The characterization results illustrate that Au exists as a single atom with the primary species as Auδ+ in Au/CeO2, forming CexAu1−xO2 structure similar to solid solution. Whereas for Au/CeO2-R catalyst, Au mainly exists as Au0, forming the Au-O-Ce structure on CeO2 surface. Significantly, the strong interaction between Au and CeO2 increases Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies content, as well as modulates their acidic property. However, the catalytic activity of Au/CeO2-R is found to be lower than Au/CeO2 as the species formed by DMC dissociation on its surface are not easily desorbed. Other transition metals supported on CeO2 are also prepared, wherein Pt/CeO2 and Pd/CeO2 exhibit good TDC selectivity. In the end, the electronegativity and catalytic activity of metals are correlated. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords 2 4-diaminotoluene Dimethyl carbonate Dimethyl toluene-2 4-dicarbamate Au/CeO2 Single-atom catalyst in situ FT-IR Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyurethane prepared via polymerization of isocyanate (-NCO) and polyol (-OH) is one of the most promising synthetic materials in use today and is extensively employed in biomedical, construction, automotive, textiles, and other industries [1–3]. Toluene diisocyanate (TDI), as the crucial raw material for polyurethane synthesis, is utilized to manufacture soft and hard polyurethane foams, coatings, adhesives, rubbers, etc. [4,5]. However, in the synthesis of TDI ( Scheme 1), highly hazardous phosgene is used as raw material, with HCl as the by-product that causes equipment corrosion [6]. This led the researchers to develop a green process with a higher atomic economy [7–9]. Among the non-phosgene methods, the synthesis of TDI from dimethyl carbonate (DMC), a green chemical, is more desirable ( Scheme 2) [10–13]. There are two steps involved in this route: the first is the synthesis of dimethyl toluene-2,4-dicarbamate (TDC), and the second step involves its decomposition. In this pathway, the only by-product is methanol, which can be recycled to synthesize DMC [14–16]. In the first step, DMC acts as both a methoxycarbonylation and N-methylation reagent. Consequently, when DMC reacts with 2,4-diaminotoluene (TDA) ( Scheme 3) [17–19], there are two possible reactions: methoxycarbonylation reaction by BAC2 mechanism or N-methylation reaction via the BAL2 mechanism. Thus, it is crucial to use efficient catalysts to improve the TDC selectivity. At present, homogeneous catalysts employed to synthesize TDC are mainly alkali catalysts, including alkoxides of alkali metals [20,21] and Lewis acid catalysts [22–27]. The alkali catalysts have relatively low activity and poor selectivity, with the N-methylation product as the main by-product. Among the Lewis acid catalysts, acetate of Zn and Pb exhibit the best activity. In this direction, Wang et al. [27] utilized Pb(OAc)2 as a catalyst and demonstrated that the yield of the TDC reached up to 97.7% at 170 °C for 4 h. Pb, however, is unsuitable for industrial use since it is not environmentally friendly. Furthermore, it has been shown that Zn(OAc)2 [22–25] and Zn4O(O2CCH3)6 [26] also exhibited excellent activity for the TDC synthesis. Compared to Zn4O(O2CCH3)6, Zn(OAc)2 offers the advantages of greater supply and lower cost, Wang et al.[25] used Zn(OAc)2 as the catalyst showing the yield of the TDC reaching up to 98.9% at 160 °C for 7 h. However, Zn(OAc)2 is difficult to separate and easy to deactivate. Thus, the issues with homogeneous catalysts drive the need for more stable heterogeneous catalysts. A lot of research has been conducted thus far using heterogeneous catalysts, including supported Zn(OAc)2 catalysts [28,29], MOFs [30], cerium-based oxides [31–34], etc. In this regard, Xue et al. [29] investigated the catalytic performance of supported Zn(OAc)2 with a yield of the TDC reaching 86% at 170 °C for 3 h. Although the study solved the separation problem of the catalyst, the deactivation of Zn(OAc)2 still exists. In another study, Corma et al. employed nano Zr-MOF-808 as a catalyst to obtain 91% of the yield of TDC [30]. They further assembled the as-prepared catalyst into the mesoporous MCM-41 to prepare Zr-MOF-808 @MCM-41, which exhibited better activity and stability than that of nano Zr-MOF-808. It was reported that the yield of TDC was maintained at 80% even after 6 recycling tests. Unfortunately, the complex synthesis processes of MOFs material make them unsuitable for industrial applications. Also, cerium-based oxides have been utilized for TDC synthesis, demonstrating their good catalytic performance [31–34]. Nanocrystalline CeO2 was used by Corma et al. to catalyze the synthesis of TDC with a selectivity of 56% [31]. However, the catalyst had low stability, and the yield decreased drastically after 3 recycling tests. The decrease in the activity was ascribed to the carbon deposition on the surface of the catalyst, along with the reconstruction of some crystal planes into (100) crystal planes induced by DMC [33]. Later, Rico et al. prepared a series of CeO2 doped with metals (Eu, Hf, La, Pr, Sm, Tb, Y, and Zr) to improve the catalytic activity and stability of nanocrystalline CeO2 [34]. It was observed that the Ce0.98Zr0.2O2 showed good catalytic activity for the synthesis of TDC with 100% TDA conversion and 88% TDC selectivity. However, the selectivity dropped to roughly 40% after 4 recycling tests. In addition, the same group also prepared Au/CeO2 catalyst with nano CeO2 as a carrier, demonstrating 99% of TDA conversion and 97% TDC selectivity [31]. Its catalytic performance was also stable after being recycled three times. It was noticed that Au loading significantly improved the TDC selectivity as well as stability, but no studies of the interaction between Au and CeO2 have been done in this report. In recent years, the Au/CeO2 catalyst has been extensively investigated in reactions such as CO oxidation, water gas shift conversion, and volatile organic compounds conversion [35–37]. It possessed unique interfacial features because of the reversible conversion between Ce3+ and Ce4+ and the strong interaction between Au and CeO2, which led to excellent activity, selectivity, and stability [38]. Nevertheless, the majority of the recent research focused on the redox reaction, and there have been no discussions concerning the effect of the interaction between Au and CeO2 on the acidic and basic properties of the catalyst. Herein, we prepared nano-CeO2 using a simple calcination method, followed by the synthesis of Au/CeO2 via a deposition-precipitation technique. The interaction between Au and CeO2 in Au/CeO2 and reduced Au/CeO2 catalyst is investigated. Furthermore, the effect of this interaction on the acidity and activity of these two catalysts is discussed. Besides, the impact of other transition metals on the catalytic activity of CeO2 is examined with the correlation between their electronegativities and catalytic activities. This provides a way to modulate the acidic properties of the catalysts by utilizing the interactions between metals and CeO2. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All reagents were used as received without further purification. 2.1.1 Preparation of CeO2 5 g Ce(CH3COO)3 (99.9%, Rhawn) or 5 g Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (99.5%, Rhawn) was calcined at 600 °C in air atmosphere for 2 h to prepare CeO2, which were denoted as CeO2-A and CeO2-N respectively. 5 g commercial nano CeO2 (99.0%, Rhawn) was also calcined under the above conditions before use, which was denoted as CeO2-C. 2.1.2 Preparation of Au/CeO2 Au/CeO2 catalyst was prepared by deposition-precipitation method [31]. 0.2 mol/L NaOH solution was added into HAuCl4·4 H2O aqueous solution (0.04 g/mL, precursor: HAuCl4·4 H2O AR, Sinopharm) until pH= 10. This solution was dropped into the suspension composed of CeO2 (3 g) and distilled water (50 mL). Then adjusted its pH to 10 with NaOH solution (0.2 mol/L) and stirred vigorously at room temperature for 10 h. Finally, the solid was filtered and washed several times with distilled water to completely remove Cl-, and dried on vacuum at room temperature for 10 h to obtain Au/CeO2 catalyst. Au/CeO2 was reduced at 300 °C in 50 vol% H2/N2 atmosphere for 2 h (heating rate 1 °C/min), to obtain Au/CeO2-R. 2.1.3 Preparation of other catalysts Pt/CeO2-A and Ir/CeO2-A catalysts were prepared according to the method in 2.2.2. Pd/CeO2-A catalyst was prepared by deposition-precipitation method. 0.1 g PdCl2 was mixed with 50 mL of distilled water. HCl dropped into the mixture until pH= 2 and then stirred for 1 h at room temperature to fully dissolve PdCl2. The remaining steps were the same as in 2.2.2. M/CeO2-A (M=Rh, Ag, Ru, Cu, Co) catalysts were prepared by deposition-precipitation method. 3 g CeO2-A and 50 mL distilled water were mixed to obtain the suspension, then dropped the metal salt solution into the suspension. Adjusted its pH to 9 with Na2CO3 solution (0.2 mol/L), and stirred vigorously at room temperature for 10 h. Finally, the solid was filtered and washed several times with distilled water, and dried on vacuum at room temperature for 10 h to obtain M/CeO2-A (M=Rh, Ag, Ru, Cu, Co). 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 FOCUS X-ray powder diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA, using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15 418 nm). The data was collected at a scanning rate of 6°/min in the 2θ range from 10° to 90°. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were performed on a FEI Talos F200S electron microscope operated at 200 kV. The samples for TEM measurements were prepared by ultra-sonically suspending catalyst powder in ethanol and placing a drop of the suspension to a holey amorphous carbon film on a Cu grid. Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM images were obtained using a JEM-ARM30F equipped with a spherical aberration corrector working at 200 keV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were conducted on a Escalab 250Xi spectrometer from Thermo Scientific, USA. The voltage and power for the measurements were 14.6 kV and 200 W, respectively. All the binding energies were calibrated with the C 1 s peaking at 284.8 eV. Bruker A300 EPR spectrometer was used to collect the Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of samples. NH3-TPD was carried out with an AutoChem 2920 chemisorption instrument. The Hiden ExQ mass spectrometry was used to confirm the desorbed gas. The content of Au components in the studied samples was determined by Agilent 725-ES ICP-OES inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer. Py-IR measurement was carried out on a Thermo NICOLET NEXUS-470 spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector. 20 mg of samples was pressed into a self-supporting disc and loaded into in a quartz sample holder with CaF2 window. 32 scans were averaged using a resolution of 4 cm−1. The samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 60 min in 10−3 Pa. After cooling down to room temperature, the background spectrum was collected. Then pyridine was introduced into the cell and the sample was exposed to pyridine vapor for 30 min. Then the physically adsorbed pyridine was removed at 200 °C and 10−2 Pa for 1 h. When the temperature of the cell drops to room temperature, collect the spectrum. In situ FT-IR measurement was carried out on a Thermo NICOLET NEXUS-470 spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector. 20 mg of samples was pressed into a self-supporting disc and loaded into Specac in situ IR cell (model P/N 05,850) with ZnSe windows. 32 scans were averaged using a resolution of 4 cm−1. The samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 60 min in a flow of N2 (40 mL/min). After cooling down to 40 °C, the background spectrum was collected. Then DMC was introduced into the cell through the bubbling device and the sample was exposed to DMC vapor for 20 min. After the physical adsorption, N2 were introduced and maintained for 60 min (40 °C). The IR spectrum were collected every 10 min 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The methoxycarbonylation reaction of TDA was carried out in 50 mL Hastelloy autoclave (Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd). 1 g catalyst, 0.97 g TDA (98.0%, Aladdin) and 20 mL DMC (99.0%, Macklin) were added in the autoclave, sealed and replaced with N2 for 3 times. After that, the autoclave was heated to 170 °C and react for 10 h. After the reaction, the reaction liquid and catalyst were separated by centrifugation, and the catalyst was washed with anhydrous ethanol for several times and then dried on vacuum at room temperature. The reaction liquid was mixed with ethanol lotion, and was analyzed by American Waters-515 high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). Chromatographic conditions were as follows: Shim-pack VP-ODS (250 mm × 4.6 mm 5 µm) chromatographic column was used at the flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. The detection wavelength was 254 nm and CH3OH/H2O (50/50, V/V) was used as the mobile phase. 2.4 Preparation of intermediate products The standard samples of by-products, methyl 2-methyl-5-amino-N-phenyl-carbamate (2-TMC) and methyl 3-amino-4-methyl-N-phenylcarbamate (4-TMC), were prepared by ourself. Using Zn(OAC)2 as catalyst, DMC reacted with 2-methyl-5-nitroaniline and 3-nitro-4-methylaniline at 160 °C for 7 h, respectively. The reaction solution was filtered and then distilled on vacuum to obtain yellow solid. The yellow solid was dissolved in ethanol and reacted with H2 at 60 °C for 2 h with 5 wt% Pd/C as catalyst (Scheme S1). After the reaction, the reaction mixture was filtered on vacumm and the filtrate was distilled under reduced pressure to obtain white solid. This solid was recrystallized in ethanol to obtain TMC standard samples. The samples were analyzed by 1 H NMR (Fig. S1 . a), 13 C NMR (Fig. S1 . b), mass spectrometry (Fig. S1 . c) and infrared spectroscopy (Fig. S1 . d). 2.5 HPLC-MS In order to qualitatively analyze the by-products in the reaction system, HPLS-MS was used to analyze the reaction solution. The HPLC-MS equipped with an electron spray ionization detector in positive mode (ESI). The chromatographic condition was the same as that of in Section 2.4. The list of compounds and diagnostic mass-to-charge (m/z) ratios of the ESI+-MS spectra are summarized in Section S2. 2.6 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation Gaussian 16 code discovered the equilibrium electronic structures of TDA and 4-TMC and the Gaussview geometrically optimized spatial structure of TDA and 4-TMC graphicsally. All equilibrium electronic structures were optimized at the M06–2X/6–311 + +G(d,p) basis set level using DFT method. Zero-point energy corrections for single-point energy calculations were performed on all-fixed points using single and double excitation coupled cluster theory, including perturbation correction settings for the triple excitation CCSD(T)/aug-cc-pVDZ basis. The frequency calculation of M06–2X/6–311 + +G(d,p) adopted the zero point vibration energy (ZPE) correction, which improved the accuracy of the reaction energy values. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening The methoxycarbonylation reaction of TDA is catalyzed using CeO2-A, CeO2-N, and CeO2-C, respectively. The results are shown in Table 1 (No. 2–4). It is observed that the conversion of TDA is only 10.5% without a catalyst (No. 1). However, the conversion of TDA increases significantly, reaching close to the complete conversion using CeO2 as the catalyst (No. 2–4). Notably, the TDC selectivity over CeO2-A, CeO2-N, and CeO2-C catalysts differs, and the best catalytic performance is achieved by CeO2-A with 98.2% TDA conversion and 69.3% TDC selectivity. In the reaction of DMC and TDA, there are two major intermediates, 2-TMC and 4-TMC, which are shown in the following reaction ( Scheme 4). This suggests that toluene mono-carbamate (TMC) is initially formed when DMC reacts with TDA then TMC is further reacted to form TDC. Besides 2-TMC, and 4-TMC, other by-products, such as N-methylated products and polyurea, are also found [33]. The mass spectral analysis of the reaction solution using CeO2-C as a catalyst is shown in section S2. Furthermore, to identify the amino group in TDA that undergoes methoxycarbonylation first, the conformational optimization and frequency analysis of TDA and 4-TMC molecules are carried out at the level of M06–2X/6–311 + +G(d,p) basis using density functional theory (DFT) to obtain their stable geometrical configurations ( Fig. 1). The combined values of the electronic and thermodynamic energies of the TDA and 4-TMC molecules with zero-point energy correction are 380.4 hartree and 607.3 hartree, respectively. The results of the frequency calculation reveal that there is no false frequency, confirming the reliability of the analysis. The optimized geometrical configurations of TDA and 4-TMC exhibit good stability, which serves as the basis for calculating the bond dissociation energy (BDE) of N-H bonds in TDA and 4-TMC, as shown in Fig. 1 . There are two -NH2 groups in TDA. The energy of the N4-H bond in the 4-position and the N2-H bond in the 2-position are 342.9 kJ·mol–1 and 346.1 kJ·mol–1, respectively ( Table 2). Importantly, the energy of the N4-H bond is lower than that of the N2-H bond, indicating that methoxycarbonylation can easily take place on the N4-H bond. Consequently, 4-TMC is more readily formed than 2-TMC. Table 1 (No. 2–4) displays that the selectivity of 4-TMC is greater than that of 2-TMC, which is in accordance with the calculated results. Meanwhile, the loaded Au catalysts are prepared for the methoxycarbonylation of TDA with CeO2-A, CeO2-N, and CeO2-C as carriers, and the results are shown in Table 1 (No. 5, 7, 9). Compared to bare CeO2-A, CeO2-N, and CeO2-C catalysts, the Au loading improves the selectivity of TDC to some extent. Among them, Au/CeO2-A exhibits the best catalytic activity with 98.3% TDA conversion and 87.8% TDC selectivity. Further, when Au/CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-N, and Au/CeO2-C catalysts are reduced (denoted as Au/CeO2-A-R, Au/CeO2-N-R, and Au/CeO2-C-R, respectively), TDA conversion and TDC selectivity drop to different degrees (No. 6, 8, 10). The aforementioned results present that the catalytic activity of CeO2 prepared from different cerium sources is different. Additionally, TDC selectivity is improved after loading Au; however, the reduced Au/CeO2 decreases TDA conversion and TDC selectivity to different degrees. Notably, the reduction of Au/CeO2 may affect the valence of Au species and CeO2. Owing to this, the reduced CeO2-A (denoted as CeO2-A-R) is used as the catalyst in TDC synthesis to observe the effect on the catalytic activity, as shown in Table 1 (No. 11). It is important to highlight here that the TDA conversion over CeO2-A-R is close to that of CeO2-A with decreased TDC selectivity by 9.2%. In contrast to Au/CeO2-A, TDC selectivity over Au/CeO2-A-R drops by 45.7%. This suggests that the primary cause of the loss in catalyst performance following reduction is related to the Au species. Further, the CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts are characterized to investigate the interaction between Au and CeO2 and its correlation with the catalytic activity. 3.2 XRD Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts. The diffraction peaks centered at 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7°, and 79.1° corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) planes of fluorite CeO2 (JCPDS No. 43–1002) appeared in all the three catalysts. Meanwhile, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Au species did not appear in the Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts, indicating that Au is evenly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst, with its size below the detection limit of XRD. In addition, the diffraction peak of the (111) plane in the Au/CeO2-A catalyst is shifted to a higher angle in comparison to CeO2-A, while it is not shifted in Au/CeO2-A-R catalyst, as can be seen in the inset of Fig. 2. 3.3 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms Fig. 3 (a) shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R. The three catalysts exhibit a type IV isotherm with an obvious H4-type hysteresis loop, indicating the mesoporous structure of the catalysts. The pore sizes of these catalysts are mainly distributed in the range of 3–5 nm, as displayed in Fig. 3 (b). In addition, the textural properties of catalysts are shown in Table S2. It is noted that the specific surface area, average pore volume, and average pore diameter of CeO2-A are not significantly changed by the Au loading. 3.4 SEM and TEM Fig. 3 (c) displays the SEM image of CeO2-A showing irregular flakes, some of which can be combined to form flower-like CeO2 (Fig. 3(d)). The HAADF-TEM image of CeO2-A indicated the presence of a large number of pores on CeO2-A, facilitating sufficient contact between the feedstock and the catalyst. This may have happened due to the pore-forming effect of the gas generated during the thermal decomposition of cerium acetate. Fig. 3(f) displays the HRTEM image of CeO2-A, where CeO2-A mainly exposes the (100) plane with a lattice spacing of 0.27 nm. Furthermore, it is observed that Au is mostly dispersed as single atoms (bright spots marked with white boxes) over the surface of the catalyst, as depicted in Fig. 3(g). The results are consistent with the study of Zhang et al. [36]. Meanwhile, the HAADF-STEM image of Au/CeO2-A-R in Fig. 3(h) shows that Au exists in the form of single atoms (bright spots marked with white boxes) with no signs of clusters or nanoparticles in the observed regions.Furthermore, the images of Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R with different magnification were shown in Fig. S3. 3.5 XPS and EPR The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Au 4 f shows the binding energy peaks at 83.8 eV and 87.4 eV attributing to Au0, as shown in Fig. 4 (a). The binding energy peaks at 84.4 eV and 89.1 eV are assigned to Au+, while peaks at 85.3 eV and 89.2 eV correspond to Au3+ [36], indicating the presence of Au0, Au+, and Au3+ on Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R. The contents of Au0, Au+, and Au3+ are listed in Table 3. Notably, the major species in Au/CeO2-A catalyst is Auδ+ (sum of Au+ and Au3+), with a content of 88.6%. Whereas Au species primarily exist in the form of Au0 with a content of 85.4% in Au/CeO2-A-R catalyst. The XPS spectrum of Ce 3d presented in Fig. 4(b) is fitted into ten peaks using the Gaussian-Lorentzian function, wherein the peaks of 3d 3/2 and 3d 5/2 orbitals are labeled with u and v, respectively. The peaks of u0, u', v0, and v' belong to Ce3+, whereas the peaks of u'', u′', u, v′', and v are related to Ce4+ [39]. The content of Ce3+ is calculated from the ratio of the sum of the Ce3+ peak areas to that of the total peak area of cerium species, [40] and the results are listed in Table 3. Noticeably, the Ce3+ content in Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts is higher than that of CeO2-A. Furthermore, the analysis of O 1 s XPS spectrum reveals the peaks at 529.5 eV, 530.7 eV, and 532.5 eV corresponding to CeO2 lattice oxygen (Ce-O, OL) [41], oxygen vacancy (OV) [41,42], and surface adsorbed hydroxyl (OOH) [41]. The content of OV in Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts is higher than CeO2-A, with the highest in Au/CeO2-A-R catalyst (Table 3). Thus, it is concluded that the content of Ce3+ and OV in the catalyst increases due to the support of Au. Next, the catalyst is characterized using EPR, and the results are shown in Fig. 4(d). The two characteristic signals in the EPR map, g = 1.962 and g = 1.943, represent Ce3+ species with distorted asymmetric structures [43]. At the same time, the unpaired electrons cause the symmetric peak at g = 2.004 at the oxygen vacancy [44]. Compared to CeO2-A, the peak intensity of Ce3+ and OV in Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts is significantly higher. The results are consistent with the XPS analysis. Based on the aforementioned results of Au/CeO2-A, the diffraction peak of the (111) plane shifts to a higher angle in the XRD pattern, and the Au species mainly exists in the form of Au+ and Au3+. The radius of Au3+ (0.085 nm) is smaller than that of Ce3+ (0.110 nm) and Ce4+ (0.097 nm). Some of Au is doped into the CeO2 lattice, which causes lattice distortion and the shifting of the diffraction peak. Therefore, CexAu1−xO2 structure similar to a solid solution is formed in Au/CeO2-A catalyst [45]. Meanwhile, the diffraction peak of the (111) crystal plane of CeO2 in Au/CeO2-A-R does not shift, and the Au species on the surface mainly exists in the form of Au0. The radius of Au0 (0.144 nm) is greater than the radius of Ce3+ (0.110 nm) and Ce4+ (0.097 nm). Thus, most of the Au metal migrates from the CeO2 lattice to the surface to form an Au-O-Ce structure during H2 treatment. Therefore, there is a strong interaction between Au and CeO2 in Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts, resulting in the formation of more Ce3+ and Ov. 3.6 Py-IR and NH3-TPD The Py-IR spectra of CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts show the absorption peaks at 1540 cm–1 and 1450 cm–1 corresponding to the characteristic peaks of Brӧnsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively ( Fig. 5 (a)) [46]. The ratio of Lewis acid to Brӧnsted acid (L/B) on these three catalysts is shown in Table 4. Importantly, the L/B of Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts is higher than that of CeO2, suggesting that the loading of Au is beneficial for the formation of Lewis acid sites. Meanwhile, the NH3-TPD profiles of CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R depict that the strength of acidic sites on the solid acid surface is divided into weak (<300 °C), medium (300–450 °C), and strong (>450 °C) on the basis of the desorption temperature of NH3 [47]. It is evident that there are weak and medium acid sites on the CeO2-A surface, with the weak acid sites predominating. In addition, three NH3 desorption peaks appear in the NH3-TPD profiles of Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R, indicating the weak, medium, and strong acid sites on their surface. Table 4 presents the acid amount of CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R surfaces. The acid amount of Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R is significantly higher than CeO2-A, with Au/CeO2-A-R having the most significant acid amount. Furthermore, the increased acid amount mostly comes from medium and strong acid sites, indicating that the loading of Au increases the strength and amount of acidic sites on the surface of CeO2. Thus, it can be concluded that there are many Brӧnsted acid sites on the CeO2-A surface, while Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts possess more Lewis acid sites. This is ascribed to the formation of the CexAu1−xO2 structure in Au/CeO2-A, leading to excess positive charge, thereby forming more Lewis acid sites. Besides, Au/CeO2-A-R catalyst has more Lewis acid sites in comparison to Au/CeO2-A, which might be due to the migration of Au from the CeO2 lattice to its surface to form the Au-O-Ce bond, occupying more surface hydroxyl groups; thus, reducing Brӧnsted acid sites and increasing Lewis acid sites. In addition, the acidic strength of Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R is also enhanced than CeO2 due to the interaction between Au and CeO2 in Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts, forming CexAu1−xO2 structure and the Ce-O-Au bond, respectively. As previously explained, when DMC reacts with TDA, TMC is the initial product, while TDC is formed by further methoxycarbonylation of TMC. As illustrated in Table 1, the TDC selectivity over Au/CeO2-A is better than that of over CeO2-A with the similar TDA conversion, depicting the stronger ability of Au/CeO2-A to convert TMC into TDC. Furthermore, Table 2 displays the results of Gaussian calculations of the N-H bond energy of the 2-NH2 group in 4-TMC, which came out to be 496.0 kJ·mol–1 higher than that of the 2-NH2 group in TDA. Consequently, it is more challenging to carry out the methoxycarbonylation of the 2-NH2 group in 4-TMC. Thus, it is concluded from the results of Py-IR and NH3-TPD analysis that the Au/CeO2-A catalyst has more Lewis acid sites with stronger strength, effectively catalyzing the conversion of TMC to TDC with excellent TDC selectivity. Moreover, according to the results of XPS, the Ce3+ content on the surface of Au/CeO2-A is higher than that on the CeO2-A catalyst. Also, Auδ+ ions are present on the surface of Au/CeO2-A. Since the reaction of TDA and DMC is an acid-catalyzed reaction, Ce3+, Ce4+, and Auδ+ could be used as acidic sites to catalyze the methoxycarbonylation of TDA. Further, the TDC selectivity over Au/CeO2-A is higher than that over CeO2-A, which may be related to the higher content of Ce3+ or Auδ+ on the surface of Au/CeO2-A. The oxygen vacancies of Au/CeO2-A are also high, which interact with the oxygen atom of the carbonyl group in DMC, facilitating the adsorption and dissociation of DMC [33,34]. It may be regarded as the Lewis acid site, thus, making the synthesis of TDC easier. It is therefore inferred that the improved catalytic performance of Au/CeO2-A may also be due to its larger oxygen vacancy content. The Au/CeO2-A-R also possesses higher Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy content than Au/CeO2-A but depicts the worst TDC selectivity. Thus, to determine this discrepancy in the performance, the adsorption of DMC on the surface of CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R is investigated by in situ FT-IR. 4 DMC adsorption on different catalysts by in situ FT-IR As shown in the FT-IR spectra of DMC in Fig. 6 . (I)-a, the bands at 2965 cm–1 and 2865 cm–1 are ascribed to the typical C-H stretching vibration of methyl in DMC, whereas the band at 1460 cm–1 corresponds to the C-H bending vibration of methyl. The peaks at 1782 cm–1 and 1767 cm–1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of CO in DMC [48], and the peak at 1290 cm–1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of C-O-C [49]. Moreover, when DMC is adsorbed on the surface of CeO2-A, an inverted peak appears at 3442 cm–1, indicating the interaction of some terminal hydroxyl groups on the surface of CeO2-A with DMC (Fig. 6 . (I) b-g) [48]. Besides, the two bands at 1767 cm–1 and 1782 cm–1 ascribed to CO in DMC disappeared with time, indicating that DMC dissociated on the surface of CeO2-A, which was consistent with the study of Corma et al. [31] However, several new peaks appear; the peaks at 2946 cm–1 and 2835 cm–1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the C-H bond in -CH3 [50,51], while the bands at 1593 cm–1 and 1572 cm–1 are assigned to methoxycarbonyl (-COOCH3) [31] and monomethyl carbonate species (-OCOOCH3), respectively [45]. In addition, the peaks at 2913 cm–1, 2807 cm–1, 1103 cm–1, and 1039 cm–1 are corresponded to -OCH3 [50–52]. The appearance of the 1103 cm–1 band indicates that -OCH3 is adsorbed on Ce4+ in a linear manner ( Fig. 7 . Type I on-top methoxy), while 1039 cm–1 shows that -OCH3 is adsorbed on Ce4+ in a bridging manner (Fig. 7 . Type II' bridged methoxy) [53]. Above all, when DMC is adsorbed on the surface of CeO2-A, dissociation occurs to generate -OCH3, -COOCH3, or -CH3, -OCOOCH3. The formation of -COOCH3 is conducive to the TDC synthesis. In order to show the trend of species formed by DMC dissociation over time more clearly, the part of the infrared spectra in Fig. 6 with a wave number of 1140–1000 cm–1 and 1600–1150 cm–1 were enlarged, as shown in Fig. 8. Fig. 8 . (a)− 1 represents the time evolution of the peak height of methoxy intermediates during N2 purge over CeO2-A. It is noted that the peak height of bridged methoxy is higher than that of on-top methoxy on the CeO2-A surface, depicting that the on-top methoxy is more likely to desorb. Moreover, the peak height of -COOCH3 is close to that of -OCOOCH3, as shown in Fig. 8 . (b)− 1, suggesting the same degree of their desorption. Next, the IR spectra of DMC adsorbed on Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 . (II) b-g and Fig. 6 . (III), respectively. Similar to CeO2-A, DMC is also dissociated on the surface of these two catalysts. It can be seen from Fig. 8 . (a)− 2, and 3 that the peak height of bridged methoxy on the surfaces of Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R is higher than that of on-top methoxy and thus, on-top methoxy is more likely to desorb. The difference is that there are more on-top methoxy adsorbed on Au/CeO2-A surface than that on Au/CeO2-A-R. Moreover, a small amount of type II (1077 cm–1) and type III (1109 cm–1) methoxyl groups are also observed on the surface of the Au/CeO2-A catalyst (Fig. 6 . (II)). In addition, DMC dissociates into -COOCH3 and -OCOOCH3 on the surface of Au/CeO2-A-R; in contrast, only the bond of -COOCH3 appears at 1598 cm–1 for Au/CeO2-A, showing that the surface of Au/CeO2-A is beneficial for the formation of -COOCH3. The time evolution of peak height for -COOCH3 and -OCOOCH3 species are shown in Fig. 8 . (b,c)− 2. The -COOCH3 on the surface of Au/CeO2-A is easily desorbed with time; however, the -COOCH3 and -OCOOCH3 species on the surface of Au/CeO2-A-R are difficult to desorb, which may be related to the different acidity of the catalyst. Based on the above findings, Au/CeO2-A is more favorable for the dissociation of DMC into on-top methoxy and -COOCH3 species, leading to the TDC synthesis. Also, these species are easily desorbed from the surface of the catalyst, facilitating the next step of the reaction. Thus, itis concluded that TDC selectivity is improved over Au/CeO2-A. 5 Effect of other transition metals on the catalytic activity of CeO2-A As discussed previously, the interaction between Au and Ce improves TDC selectivity over Au/CeO2-A catalyst. Does other transition metal also have the same effect? For this purpose, M/CeO2-A (M is Pt, Pd, Ru, Ag, Ir, Cu, and Co) are prepared, and their catalytic activity is investigated. As displayed in Table 5, besides Au, the loading of Pt and Pd also improve the selectivity of CeO2-A, while Ru, Ag, and Ir have little effect on TDC selectivity. As for Cu and Co, the TDC selectivity significantly decreases, demonstrating the different interactions between different metals and CeO2. Some metals promote the synthesis of TDC, while others may inhibit the synthesis of TDC. Therefore, it is important to select the appropriate metal. Notably, the strong interaction between Au and CeO2 in Au/CeO2-A is the key for enhancing the TDC selectivity. This interaction results from the formation of Mn+-O-Ce3+/4+ structure, where the degree of electron transfer affects the acid type and acid strength of the catalyst. Moreover, different metals M have different abilities to attract electrons, further affecting the electron transfer between metal and support. Therefore, the Pauling electronegativity values (EN) [54] of the above transition metal elements are correlated with the selectivity of the TDC, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . The electronegativity of these transition metal elements and TDC selectivity presents a certain degree of positive correlation. Highly electronegative elements, such as Au, Pt, and Pd, have stronger electron transfer ability with CeO2, which can modify the acidity of the catalyst and effectively enhance the catalytic performance of the catalyst. 6 Conclusion (1) Nano CeO2-A prepared with Ce(CH3COO)3 as precursor exhibited better TDC selectivity of 69.3%. To some extent, Au loading improved the TDC selectivity with Au/CeO2-A demonstrating the best catalytic performance with TDC selectivity of 87.8%. However, after reducing the Au/CeO2 (abbreviated as Au/CeO2-A-R) catalyst, the TDA conversion and TDC selectivity decreased to varying degrees. (2) The characterization results of CeO2-A, Au/CeO2-A, and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts revealed that Au existed as a single atom. It was observed that Auδ+ was the main species in Au/CeO2 and formed the CexAu1-xO2 structure similar to a solid solution. While it mainly existed in the form of Au0 in Au/CeO2-A-R, forming an Au-O-Ce structure on the surface of CeO2. Notably, the strong interaction between Au and CeO2-A increased the content of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies in Au/CeO2-A and Au/CeO2-A-R catalysts. It also increased the Lewis acid sites as well as their strength and acid amount. (3) Moreover, the strong interaction between Au and CeO2-A changed the acidic properties of the catalyst, increasing the TDC selectivity. Although the acidic properties of Au/CeO2-A-R were changed, the -COOCH3 and -OCOOCH3 species formed by the DMC dissociation on its surface were not easily desorbed, inhibiting the catalytic reaction further. It was observed that the formation of the -COOCH3 species was more favorable on the surface of Au/CeO2-A, making it a better catalyst for TDC synthesis. (4) In addition to Au, Pt/CeO2-A and Pd/CeO2-A also displayed good selectivity for the TDC synthesis. It was noticed that the electronegativity of these transition metals and the TDC selectivity presented a certain degree of positive correlation. coredata.dc:description: In the reaction of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and 2,4-diaminotoluene (TDA), Au/CeO2 exhibits higher selectivity than CeO2 for dimethyl toluene-2,4-dicarbamate (TDC). However, its catalytic activity drops after H2 reduction (denoted as Au/CeO2-R). The characterization results illustrate that Au exists as a single atom with the primary species as Auδ+ in Au/CeO2, forming CexAu1−xO2 structure similar to solid solution. Whereas for Au/CeO2-R catalyst, Au mainly exists as Au0, forming the Au-O-Ce structure on CeO2 surface. Significantly, the strong interaction between Au and CeO2 increases Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies content, as well as modulates their acidic property. However, the catalytic activity of Au/CeO2-R is found to be lower than Au/CeO2 as the species formed by DMC dissociation on its surface are not easily desorbed. Other transition metals supported on CeO2 are also prepared, wherein Pt/CeO2 and Pd/CeO2 exhibit good TDC selectivity. In the end, the electronegativity and catalytic activity of metals are correlated.
coredata.dc:title: Single-atom Au-modified CeO2 catalyst: Structure and its catalytic performance in 2,4-diaminotoluene methoxycarbonylation reaction
